<p>There are a lot of tutorials out there about how to set up and use <a href="https://www.ros.org">ROS</a>. But all of them assume that the intention is to have ROS take over the default environment. This becomes very problematic when you only have one development machine and are working on a lot of other projects -- dependency conflicts are one of the main pain-points when using ROS.</p>
<p>One solution is to consider containerizing your development environments. While virtual machines have their place in this solution, it's typically not viable because robotics development is focused on as near real-time performance as possible. Like ROS, <a href="https://www.docker.com">Docker</a> has enjoyed a lot of success and has an equally rich set of tutorials; most are focused around deployment of some web service. It gives you the advantage of using the actual system hardware while simply tricking the environment its running upon. But Docker can be challenging to ensure grapical applications (like <a href="https://gazebosim.org">Gazebo</a>) function properly.</p>
<p>So let's walk through how to get this set up!</p>
<p><strong>Disclaimer</strong>: The following was implemented on Ubuntu 20.04 Desktop. This process likely works with other versions of Linux and can be adapted for use in Win10, but it will be up to the reader to do so.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="Installing-Docker">Installing Docker<a class="anchor-link" href="#Installing-Docker">¶</a></h1><p>The <em>de facto</em> guidance for installation is through Docker's <a href="https://docs.docker.com/engine/install/ubuntu/">documentation</a>. But we can break down the process into a few easy to manage steps:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="1.-Prepare-the-System">1. Prepare the System<a class="anchor-link" href="#1.-Prepare-the-System">¶</a></h2><p>We like to start with a clean slate.</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span class="code-line"><span></span>sudo apt remove -y docker docker-engine docker.io containerd runc <span class="c1"># Clean-slate</span></span>
</pre></div>
<p>Then let's set up the dependencies we need to get Docker installed.</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span class="code-line"><span></span>sudo apt update</span>
<span class="code-line">sudo apt install -y apt-transport-https ca-certificates curl gnupg-agent software-properties-common</span>
</pre></div>
<p>Finally, we can add the repository.</p>

<pre><span class="code-line"><code>curl -fsSL https://download.docker.com/linux/ubuntu/gpg | sudo apt-key add - # Adds the repository key to our list</span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">sudo add-apt-repository "deb [arch=amd64] https://download.docker.com/linux/ubuntu $(lsb_release -cs) stable"</span>
<span class="code-line">sudo apt update # Fetch the latest updates from our recently added repository</code></pre>
<p>If you like to live on the wild-side, you can change the option to <code>"edge"</code>, but this may create instabilities with your installation.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="2.-Install-Docker">2. Install Docker<a class="anchor-link" href="#2.-Install-Docker">¶</a></h2><p>Since we're using Aptitude, installation is a breeze:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span class="code-line"><span></span>sudo apt install -y docker-ce docker-ce-cli containerd.io</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="3.-Do-a-Test-Run-of-Docker">3. Do a Test Run of Docker<a class="anchor-link" href="#3.-Do-a-Test-Run-of-Docker">¶</a></h2><p>Docker installations can have some really odd error cases. So we're going to do a simple test to ensure everything installed properly before changing the environment further.</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span class="code-line"><span></span>sudo docker run hello-world</span>
</pre></div>
<p>This will start the basic <code>hello-world</code> container that just opens another Ubuntu instance, and echos the following message:</p>

<pre><span class="code-line"><code>Hello from Docker!</span>
<span class="code-line">This message shows that your installation appears to be working correctly.</span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">To generate this message, Docker took the following steps:</span>
<span class="code-line"> 1. The Docker client contacted the Docker daemon.</span>
<span class="code-line"> 2. The Docker daemon pulled the "hello-world" image from the Docker Hub.</span>
<span class="code-line">    (amd64)</span>
<span class="code-line"> 3. The Docker daemon created a new container from that image which runs the</span>
<span class="code-line">    executable that produces the output you are currently reading.</span>
<span class="code-line"> 4. The Docker daemon streamed that output to the Docker client, which sent it</span>
<span class="code-line">    to your terminal.</span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">To try something more ambitious, you can run an Ubuntu container with:</span>
<span class="code-line"> $ docker run -it ubuntu bash</span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">Share images, automate workflows, and more with a free Docker ID:</span>
<span class="code-line"> https://hub.docker.com/</span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">For more examples and ideas, visit:</span>
<span class="code-line"> https://docs.docker.com/get-started/</code></pre>
<p>If you run into issues, this will easily show what went wrong. Follow them or turn to <a href="https://stackoverflow.com">StackOverflow</a>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="4.-Cleanup">4. Cleanup<a class="anchor-link" href="#4.-Cleanup">¶</a></h2><p>Docker typically requires root access because the running containers will share the hardware resources with the host system. But we can configure specific users to granted it root access by default. This is done with the following:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span class="code-line"><span></span>sudo groupadd docker</span>
<span class="code-line">sudo usermod -aG docker <span class="si">${</span><span class="nv">USER</span><span class="si">}</span></span>
</pre></div>
<p>That will add yourself to the <code>docker</code> group so you can call it without root privilege (note that you needed root privilege to both generate the group and add yourself to it, so it kinda signals that you're trustworthy).</p>
<p>It's recommended that you reboot the system at this point. Most tutorials and Docker's own documentation says log out and back in again, but a refresh of the running state can shake out other issues. After rebooting, you should be able to re-run the <code>hello-world</code> container without needing root privilege.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="Ok,-So-What-Do-I-Do-With-Docker?">Ok, So What Do I Do With Docker?<a class="anchor-link" href="#Ok,-So-What-Do-I-Do-With-Docker?">¶</a></h1><p>There is an endless sea of tutorials that can walk anyone through every facet of how to use, manipulate, configure, launch, and store Docker containers. Instead, we're going to focus on the minimum subset of what's needed to install and launch our container.</p>
<p>Though <a href="https://hub.docker.com/">DockerHub</a> is a very popular way of distributing containers, we're instead going to focus on constructing one "from scratch" using a <em>Dockerfile</em>. The main motivation behind this two-fold: First, those files are very small and easier to share around. The other is because you can embed specific instructions to match it to the host-system's user instead of relying on a generic user.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="The-ROS_Box-Container">The <code>ROS_Box</code> Container<a class="anchor-link" href="#The-ROS_Box-Container">¶</a></h1><p>To begin, you'll need to download the <a href="https://github.com/jhill515/RosBox/blob/main/Dockerfile">Dockerfile</a> attached to this article (MD5 Checksum = <code>390750aec555944b0e6ac24a9e4917c8</code>). I won't walk through how to construct this file, but you can check out <a href="https://docker-curriculum.com/#dockerfile">Docker for Beginners</a> by <a href="https://prakhar.me/">Prakhar Srivastav</a> to understand the details.</p>
<p>Building is generally a breeze, but we should specify two arguments...</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span class="code-line"><span></span>docker build --build-arg <span class="nv">TZ</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="sb">`</span>cat /etc/timezone<span class="sb">`</span> <span class="se">\ </span><span class="c1"># Set timezone</span></span>
<span class="code-line">             --build-arg <span class="nv">USR</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="si">${</span><span class="nv">USER</span><span class="si">}</span> <span class="se">\ </span>           <span class="c1"># Create a default user for yourself</span></span>
<span class="code-line">             -t rosbox:1.0 .                      <span class="c1"># Tag your build with a meaningful name and use Dockerfile here</span></span>
</pre></div>
<p>This extends the <em>Open Source Robotics Foundation</em>'s container with Ubuntu 20.04 and ROS Noetic with the full desktop package. This also includes Gazebo and a number of other packages & utilities to get started on virtually any development project.</p>
<p>The build takes a little while, but you can observe what it's doing as it runs.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="Ensuring-Graphical-Support">Ensuring Graphical Support<a class="anchor-link" href="#Ensuring-Graphical-Support">¶</a></h1><p>This can be a bit tricky, but ultimately it involves ensuring that when we run the container, Docker has the right interfaces available. Essentially, we need the following when we run:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span class="code-line"><span></span>docker run -it <span class="se">\ </span>                                              <span class="c1"># Just starts the interactive session</span></span>
<span class="code-line">           --hostname rosbox <span class="se">\ </span>                                <span class="c1"># Use a good name</span></span>
<span class="code-line">           --volume<span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"</span><span class="nv">$HOME</span><span class="s2">/.Xauthority:/root/.Xauthority:rw"</span> <span class="se">\ </span><span class="c1"># Use the host's display authority credentials</span></span>
<span class="code-line">           --env<span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"DISPLAY"</span> <span class="se">\ </span>                                  <span class="c1"># Turn the display on</span></span>
<span class="code-line">           --net<span class="o">=</span>host <span class="se">\ </span>                                       <span class="c1"># Use the host's network connections</span></span>
<span class="code-line">           rosbox:1.0                                          <span class="c1"># Run the container we just built</span></span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<p>Most of the time in software engineering, designers tend to shun or gravitate towards utilizing the internal state of the module they're developing. This post isn't to discuss that. Rather, it's to show that the concept of <em>state</em> is a embedded in a wide range of structures. But first, let's try to define what's meant by state itself.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="The-Stateful-Nature-of-Things">The Stateful Nature of Things<a class="anchor-link" href="#The-Stateful-Nature-of-Things">¶</a></h1><p>Usually in signal processing and many other software applications, we like to think of things as a function. Some set of inputs <strong>x</strong> is passed to a function $f()$, and we get a response <strong>y</strong> from that function.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><img src="../images/TI_System.png" alt="Time Invariant System"></p>
<figcaption><i>Fig. 1 - Time-Invariant System Flow</i></figcaption>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>A lot of things seem to work that way: a light bulb filament gives off light proportionate to the energy applied to it. This lack of statefulness implies <em>time invariance</em>: It doesn't matter when energy is applied, the filament gives off light.</p>
<p>It's a convenient way to understand systems. This is how <em>data driven</em> systems are designed: Data goes in, transformed data comes out. But time invariance places specific requirements on the inputs themselves. When such a system is given an <em>impulse</em>, it changes its response only then and provides a transient response afterwards (which can include no response at all!). Take for example listening to the radio: if the signal is disrupted, but what if we don't want the music to abruptly stop? Many streaming services have <em>buffering</em> built into them to cache the stream so that disruptions in the signal are masked by the buffer itself. In a sense, this buffer cache is providing a state to the application: as long as it isn't empty, normal operations can progress!</p>
<p>Digital control systems are usually designed considering that the input signal may be <em>latent</em> or <em>dropped</em> an update, but they still have requirements to produce their output following some periodic. Because of this, a lot of signal processing implementations follow this model.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><img src="../images/nonTI_System.png" alt="Time Invariant System"></p>
<figcaption><i>Fig. 2 - Data-Robust System Flow</i></figcaption>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The above model now has two <strong>triggers</strong> for generating an output: one is upon receipt of new data, and another is when the timer expires. This simple model guarantees a data rate of at-least the timer rate, which is applicable in a lot of design circumstances. But the internal <strong>state</strong> of the controller changes based on the trigger because the logic for when no new data is available will activate or deactivate based on the trigger.</p>

</div>

<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In general, the above code is very functional and has a simple decision flow that can be described like this:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">

<p><img src="../images/SysSw_StateModeling_DecisionModel.png" alt="Decision Flow Diagram of Example Code"></p>
<figcaption><i>Fig 3. Decision Flow Diagram of Example Code</i></figcaption>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The code itself has a very simple flow: open the interfaces, main-loop process with backup processing when data is unavailable, and close the interfaces. And if anything goes wrong, the process handles exceptions before shutting down.</p>
<p>What's interesting is that each major block is a unique phase of operation. It takes some amount of time to execute, and <em>transition</em> to the next operation depends on how the previous concluded. In essence, we can show that this program has different <em>states of operation</em> at any given time. Thus, we can also describe this process with a <strong>state model</strong>:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">

</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>It's been said hundreds of different ways, but this resonates in many cases [<a href="Ref3">3</a>]:</p>
<blockquote><p>It should be understood that the model is, at best, a surrogate for the actual system, whose precision is subject to the assumptions and approximations made by the control designer.</p>
<p>- <em>Optimal Control & Estimation</em></p>
</blockquote>
<p>And that's just it, what we see above is merely a model describing the internal state of the process. It reveals a different facet, a different interpretation of the design which can highlight behaviors not considered by other models (in this case, the Decision Flow model)</p>

</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="State-Machines-vs-State-Models">State Machines vs State Models<a class="anchor-link" href="#State-Machines-vs-State-Models">¶</a></h1><p>Now that we can see that software can be described as having a <em>runtime state</em>, what then is the difference between this and a machine? Concisely, a <strong>state machine</strong> is a construct which <em>senses</em> events/triggers, then <em>follows</em> a pre-defined set of rules governing transition, and finally <em>executes</em> a specific set of system behaviors which may provide an additional trigger. This is a nuanced definition, and we'll explore the differences between a stateful system versus a state machine.</p>
<p>The key differentiation here is that something has to reconcile <strong>ALL</strong> events/triggers. In design, it isn't sufficient if some parts can detect a trigger (like the wrapping try-catch in the listing above). For example, in <em>Listing 1</em>, immediately after calling <code>connect()</code> with each of the interfaces, the program immediately transitions into the execution loop without any evaluation of events.</p>
<p>Another differentiator is that <strong>state machines are a software design pattern</strong>! <em>Listing 1</em> is purposefully implemented naively to highlight the anti-pattern. To maintain flexibility, the insertion or removal of a state and its associated triggers <strong>should not</strong> require a redesign of the underlying code. This design pattern isn't unique (it often is implemented via other equally flexible design patterns), but let's explore one of these.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="The-State-Machine-Pattern">The State Machine Pattern<a class="anchor-link" href="#The-State-Machine-Pattern">¶</a></h1><p>There are a lot of blog posts and Stack Overflow answers which describe how to implement a robust state machine following Functional or Object Oriented Programming paradigms. For brevity, let's review an example implementation in OOP [<a href="Ref1">1</a>]:</p>

<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 id="Listing-2---State-Machine-Pattern"><em>Listing 2 - State Machine Pattern</em><a class="anchor-link" href="#Listing-2---State-Machine-Pattern">¶</a></h4><div class="gist">

#include "MyOutputApi.h"

#include "MyTransformApi.h"

class EventCollector
{
  public:
  enum class EventType : uint8_t
  {
    Start,
    InterfacesFailed,
    InterfacesClosed,
    DataAvail,
    DataMissingSignal,
    ShutdownSignal,
    GeneralFault,
    Exit
  };
  
  EventCollector& getInstance()
  {
    static EventCollector instance;
    return instance;
  }
  
  void setEvent(const EventType& evt)
  {
    // Event precidence logic
    currentEvt = evt;
  }
  
  EventType getEvent() { return currentEvt; }
  
  private:
  EventType currentEvt{Start};
  EventCollector() = default;
};

class StateHandler
{
  public:
  void handleState() noexcept = 0;
};

class InitHandler final : public StateHandler
{
  public:
  explicit InitHandler(MyInputApi& inputApi, MyOutputApi& outputApi);
  void handleState() noexcept override; // Register I/O; set event to InterfacesOpen or InterfacesFailed
};

class FaultHandler final : public StateHandler
{
  public:
  explicit FaultHandler();
  void handleState() noexcept override; // Failure ops; set event to Exit
};

class ShutdownHandler final : public StateHandler
{
  public:
  explicit ShutdownHandler(MyInputApi& inputApi, MyOutputApi& outputApi);
  void handleState() noexcept override; // De-register I/O; set event to InterfacesFailed or Exit
};

class NominalHandler final : public StateHandler
{
  public:
  explicit InitHandler(MyInputApi& inputApi, MyOutputApi& outputApi);
  void handleState() noexcept override; // Process new data; do not set event or set to InterfacesFailed
};

class DegradedHandler final : public StateHandler
{
  public:
  explicit InitHandler(MyOutputApi& outputApi);
  void handleState() noexcept override; // Process old data; do not set event or set to InterfacesFailed
};

//--- Main -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

int main(int, char**)
{
  EventCollector& evtCollector = EventCollector::getInstance();
  MyInputApi myInput; // Set this up on a thread to listen for inputs
  MyOverseerApi myOverseerApi; // set this up on a thread to listen for commands
  MyOutputApi myOutput;
  EventCollector::EventType currentEvent{EventCollector::EventType::Start};
  
  std::map<EventCollector::EventType, std::unique_ptr<StateHandler>> myStateTable
  {
    {EventCollector::EventType::Start,             std::make_unique<InitHandler>(myInput,myOutput)},
    {EventCollector::EventType::InterfacesFailed,  std::make_unique<FaultHandler>()},
    {EventCollector::EventType::DataAvail,         std::make_unique<InitHandler>(myInput,myOutput)},
    {EventCollector::EventType::DataMissingSignal, std::make_unique<InitHandler>(myInput,myOutput)},
    {EventCollector::EventType::ShutdownSignal,    std::make_unique<InitHandler>(myInput,myOutput)},
    {EventCollector::EventType::GeneralFault,      std::make_unique<FaultHandler>()}
  };
  
  while((currentEvent = evtCollector.getEvent()) != EventCollector::EventType::Exit)
  {
    if(myStateTable.find(currentEvent) != myStateTable.end())
    {
      myStateTable[currentEvent].handleState();
    }
    else
    {
      // Unmapped state
      myStateTable[EventCollector::EventType::GeneralFault].handleState();
    }
  }
    
  return 0;
}</code></pre>

<p>Listing 2 is quite longer than Listing 1, but it is no more complex. Rather, the added length introduces a level of robustness and extensibility unavailable in Listing 1. Here, requirements are free to change with little impact to the underlying architecture. So if multiple fault-response states are needed, or if we introduce additional events triggering new states, it just becomes a matter of updating the <code>StateTable</code> mapping. Stricter state-transition control can be implemented in the <code>EventCollector</code> class (such as recognizing current state and determining if the combination of state and event warrants a change of state).</p>

<h1 id="Weaknesses-of-State-Machines">Weaknesses of State Machines<a class="anchor-link" href="#Weaknesses-of-State-Machines">¶</a></h1><p>The example application above was not selected arbitrarily. In fact, it contains properties that are amenable to using the State Machine Pattern.</p>
<p>Other than clearly identifiable states and conditions of transition, one additional requirement is necessary for this pattern: <strong>States implement non-pipeline operations</strong>. This is a very specific threading/parallelization requirement because triggers may <em>interrupt</em> the completion of a state's operation, and if the pipeline is not completely synchronized, its reactivity is gated on the slowest stage of the pipeline. This becomes increasingly complicated when Pipeline-Reduce patterns are employed (e.g., receiving push-updates of sensory-data, post-processing each, then rendering a decision).</p>
<p>Like all things engineering, <em>shoehorning</em> a solution into a design is a pathway to anti-patterns. So care must be taken when considering this approach. We'll explore these in later posts.</p>

</div>

<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="Conclusion">Conclusion<a class="anchor-link" href="#Conclusion">¶</a></h1><p>All complex systems have state, but designers should not assume that such systems truly implement a state machine. In the case of safety-engineering, this does pose unique challenges: Some systems are easily refactorable to adopt the explicit control offered by a state machine, however others cannot due to the complex nature of the algorithms they implement.</p>
<p>But some fringe benefits are apparent when implementing a state machine pattern: we can now instrument event listeners to act in parallel and have a central controller dictating which event takes precedence. This phenomenon is a significant source of "throw everything away and start over" development when requirements change, or when naive prioritization is implemented and testing reveals flaws.</p>
